On Tue, 31 Jul 2001, Jason Rogers <jason.rogers@...> wrote:

> If you are using Ant, you can use the exec command with the fork
> attribute set.

I'd rather use a <java> task than <exec> (oh, <junit> has a fork
attribute too 8-).

> From: route_m69@... [mailto:route_m69@...]

>> I have 7 test, and i want to run each of them in a separate VM. Is
>> there a way?

Not by running them in a single suite like in your example, but by
using separate invocations for each test.  You can write your own
shell script, wrapper object, whatever - or you could use Ant:

<junit fork="yes">
  <test fork="true" name="common.clock.test.Test_StandardClock_1" />
  <test fork="true" name="common.clock.test.Test_StandardClock_2" />
</junit>

but it will use the reflection mechanism all TestRunners employ
(i.e. all public methods whose name starts with test, that take no
arguments and return void will be run as testcases).  At least you
will have one VM per Testcase class.

Stefan
